content.description:
SDS right of a small tree at a right-slanting crack and make a long reach to edges then straight up the bulging face on sidepulls, edges and slopers. Can be done from a standing start at V-easy.

This problem isn't listed in the Tram Bouldering Guide but is an obvious line with some good moves that's worth a go when in the area.
content.location:
Start as for

Chai Tea

but head straight up.

content.description: SDS at a flat rail and make a long reach/deadpoint for the sloping edge above before moving right on a rail to a slanting crack in a corner to finish.
content.location:
Right side of the NW face between

Chai Tea

and

Kung Fu Grip

.

content.description:
Located on the north side of the boulder to the south.

Climb directly up the face via flakes and edges, taking care with the hollow sounding flake near the top.
Start at the long rail of Jet Li and move left into a thin tramslot, then a sloping ledge, finish straight up.

Climbs the mottled face left of the small pine tree past several horizontals to finish with huge holds.

This problem isn't listed in the Tram Bouldering Guide but is an obvious line with some good moves that's worth a go when in the area.
content.location:
Left of

Chai Tea

on the other side of the small pine tree.

content.description:
Start from a hanging flake on the undercut portion of boulder and work up and left on edges via strenuous moves with poor feet to gain an incut rail which leads to better holds.

A spotter is nice to have as you're directly over a rock at the crux.
content.location:
Right side of the NW face and just right of

Thai Chi

.

content.description: SDS at a chalked rail and then punch it up a series of incut rails to a final finishing jug all the while looking at a bad landing off the edge of a shelf - a good spot is recommended if you think you'll fall.

Stand start with hands on two small sharp crimps.   Get your feet on and move up to more crimps before a long move up and right.

With the larger holds at hand move up with an easy mantle to finish.

Crux is at the start, and if you like crimps you'll find it soft for the grade.

SDS at a slanting crack and follow it right joining

Thai Chi

for it's finish. Somewhat strenuous for the grade with sometimes tricky footwork.

Note: The line show in the Tram Bouldering Guide is wrong.
content.location: Left side of the northwest face and just right of a small pine tree.
